trail: Alamere Falls via Coast Trail from Palomarin Trailhead
review_text: Excellent Christmas Day hike on a rainy day. I took a shortcut where the arrow made of rocks on the ground points. Climbed down to the beach for a better view of the waterfall. A must do hike if you are in the Bay Area.

review_text:
At this time of the year, the fall is roaring. It is so beautiful. If you are physically fit to climb up to the top of the Bassi Fall it is even better. On the left there is a trail but at some point you will have to climb some big rocks. 

Once you are at the top, the view is breathtaking. You can even walk by the stream. When I was there, there was not anyone else so while the base of the fall is crowded, you can have peace of mind and just watch the stream and the view. 

Trail is not super well marked. GPS would be helpful. Based on the time of the day you go, the parking might be an issue.

review_text: Spent 3 days 2 nights ... camped at Lake 3 both nights. Temps on Monday (11/30) night was around 28 degrees and Tuesday (12/01) was around 30 degrees. There’s a creek about .70 miles up that you can filter water from. Or you can break through the ice at the lake to get water too. I didn’t carry more than 1L the whole trip as water is plentiful to filter during the hikes. Temps during the day were around 45 degrees, colder in the snow areas.   I brought crampons but didn’t need to use them. Some areas on the trail had ice and were very slippery, be careful. Overall a great hike and WOW, everything you see is magical and breathtaking.  Definitely want to come again with warmer temps and enjoy taking a dip in the lakes.

review_text: Early summer, hot and dry as expected. A lot of the loop is a walk on a wide, dusty road rather than a hike on a trail. We’ll check it out in another season — the winter waterfalls and greener views are probably gorgeous.

trail: Ferndell to the West Observatory Loop Trail to Griffith Observatory
review_text: Why is this trail rated easy? It’s definitely moderate. Sure it’s short, but the elevation gain happens pretty rapidly, particularly going counterclockwise as described here. I much prefer the clockwise loop, starting on the far side of the wash closer to the bathrooms—that trail has more switchbacks and an easier grade. The other side is straight up a pretty eroded firebreak.

review_text: I thought I had posted a review already.  However I was at the top of Maggie’s south peak so it might’ve not gone through.   Maggie’s peak does not disappoint.  Sure during the hike you’d maybe regret or think about all the incline you’re doing or will continue to do.  But,.... the views along the way to the top are amazing!!! Slowly Lake Tahoe opens up as you climb up and get closer to the peak.  Views of the beach line, cascade lake, fallen leaf, Mount tallac and more!  Sure this trail offers a great workout, but every inch on this hike is worth it when you reach the peak.  I’m planning on this hike again and again when I’m in gorgeous Tahoe.

trail: Hollyridge Trail to Hollywood Sign Viewpoint
review_text: we went there yesterday - it's open during covid and it's really hot with no shades. it's out & back, and for 1-way it's half up and half on ridge. when you get to a point with two forks both to the hollywood sign, remember to choose the upward longer one - the other one is to a horse riding location and to a much worse lower view. the last 0.5 mile of the trail has great view of LA city, and the view of the gorgeous hollywood sign of course! btw there are many many people, so wear mask all the time. there are many dogs, but almost no kids (quite different from similar trails in the bay area).

review_text: Our favorite trail in San Francisco. We love everything about this trail. We usually hike this all the way to the Golden gate Bridge. The views of the Golden Gate Bridge are absolutely gorgeous from this trail. Please practice good trail etiquette. Happy hiking!

review_text: First and foremost, IGNORE the mileage sign at the start. It is fake news. This was a 13.3 mile round trip hike - 6.6 to the top. It took us a while (9 hours total time) because there is ice on a lot of the trail. We had crampons but still slower going. Overall, views from the top were great but the rating is less because there weren’t many views along the way. Also, it’s cold so dress with layers. This time of year the trail is not sunny.

review_text: Great trail. Went around 3pm on a Thursday. Parking was full and very small parking lot. There’s still water flowing at the waterfall. Very enjoyable hike.

trail: Mirror Lake via Valley Loop Trail
review_text: Have done this a few times. Once when the lake was full and then just the other day when it was completely dried up. I won’t judge it during the dry times, but wow...the bugs in this area were so unbelievably bad! Don’t even bother with bug spray. Wear a net, long sleeves and pants. Even in 100 degree weather lol!
short_description: Mirror Lake via Valley Loop Trail is a 6.1 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Yosemite Valley, California that features a lake and is good for all skill levels. review_text: You are hiking through an area where cows graze so be sure to give them plenty of room. Don’t attempt to touch or agitate them. The trail itself is a broad, gravel and dirt fire road. There are benches along the route to the peak, giving you a chance to rest and enjoy the view along the way. Bring plenty of water and don’t forget to wear sunscreen since the trail is very exposed. The views from the summit are absolutely amazing - you can see for miles in every direction. Feel free to follow me on my Instagram account for more dope hiking adventures! @sertanusanmaz

trail: Santa Paula Canyon and Punch Bowls Trail
review_text:
Great hike. Certainly will do it again. 

IMPORTANT!!! From where AllTrails ends, the waterfall is NW from the end point, on Santa Paula Creek. The description sucks and we walked past it,  and thankfully we passed another hiker who told us wear to go.  

Water is crystal clear,  Trial was shaded for a good portion.  Hardly any people on a Tuesday of Thanksgiving Break. Jump in the water, feels amazing.  Sure it’s November and the high was 65 today, but cold dips in spots like that are greats
short_description: Santa Paula Canyon and Punch Bowls Trail is a 6.6 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Santa Paula, California that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. trail: Castle Rock, Saratoga Gap and Ridge Trail Loop
review_text: Did up to 9.3 miles then had to take the main road 35 back to the car since I started late and it was getting dark. All the incline was already done though. This would be a great long, relaxing hike during hot summer days as it is practically all shaded. Some parts of the trail were very narrow and unkept, while other parts were wide. Only saw like 3 people on the trail on a Friday afternoon. Light-moderate difficulty. Inclines were pretty mellow. I actually jogged like half of the hike to try to beat the dark, took me 2.5 hrs. Whole body aches now lol. Views weren't all that spectacular. Nice foresty feel with crisp/fresh air. Spotty cell services. No parking fee at the starting parking lot

review_text:

Park you car at Square Valley is the best, tram will drop you back right there.
This is one of the hike show me how much man can do, (they have swimming pool, retreat...everything up there at 8,200 feet high)
Spend sometime up there before you get down,
You will see people are smart and hard worker 
Thank for everyone put up this trail 
Will come back one day.

review_text: Beautiful hike. I went in December so the river was low and the falls were frozen, but since it was off-peak, I had the trail all to myself. It was very peaceful with the sound of the river babbling by. Beautiful views along the way.

review_text: Started at 8:30 am and it was too hot. No shade on the treck up hill which made it hard. Would have been more fun if it was a cooler day. Did not climb into the waterfall as it seemed too steep and a bit dangerous.

review_text: Parking was pushed further back and the trail is closed m-f about 1 mile in. You can go around on the JMT. 6 miles round trip to Clark point.

review_text: Snowy

trail: Vernal Falls and Clark Point via Mist and John Muir Loop
review_text: The Mist portion of the trail is paved and pretty crowded, even in winter, though the views are lovely. Things thin out and get more trail-like once the JMT starts on the far side of the bridge, and it’s steep and fun with lots of switchbacks climbing the side of the valley. I went up and back on the JMT as the Mist trail is closed for the winter past the bridge. I enjoyed the hike, but the trail was covered in packed-down snow and refrozen ice, and there were a lot of folks up there who were not prepared for the conditions—I saw a few near tumbles. Actual hiking boots with good tread are not optional, and trekking poles and microspikes are a really good idea. I ended up having to lend my poles to someone in sneakers who wouldn’t have have made it back down uninjured without them, but I was fine because I had my spikes on. It’s a good thing I was there because she still had to descend so carefully we got back to the paved portion of the trail well after last light and only I had a headlamp. Winter hiking can go wrong in a hurry, folks, don’t assume that because Yosemite is a heavily maintained park that all the trails are safe. Gear up appropriately for the temps and trail conditions and make sure you have enough light to get back.

trail: Whittemore Gulch and Harkins Ridge Loop Trail
review_text: Beautiful views, well maintained, and good signage. I believe there is a trailhead at the bottom if you would rather ascend then descend. At this posted trailhead, you will descend then ascend, regardless of going counterclockwise or clockwise.
